Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5P2C-YV61-JB20-G0DD-00000-00Ping An Insurance Group Co of China Ltd Fintech Transformation - Final2017-07-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:38ZLexisNexis071417a10731558.758Ping An Insurance Group Co of China LtdFintech Transformation - Final

Corporate Participants

* Ericson Chan

* James Garner

* Ricky Ou

* Sin Yin Tan

Ping An Insurance (Group) Company of China, Ltd. - Chief Operation Officer, Chief Information Officer and EVP

Conference Call Participants

* Charles Zhou

Crédit Suisse AG, Research Division - VP

* Kailesh Mistry

HSBC, Research Division - Head of Financials Equity Research, Asia-Pacific and Analyst

* Kelvin Chu

UBS Investment Bank, Research Division - Associate Analyst and Director

* Mancy Sun

Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Research Division - Equity Analyst

* Myung Wook Kim

JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - VP

Presentation

JAMES GARNER: Great. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome. For those of you that don't know me, my name is James Garner. I joined Ping An Group right at the beginning of this year as Chief Strategist and Head of Investor Relations. I've been an outside observer of Ping An Group for over 8 years. But that said, since joining, I've come to understand many misunderstandings that the financial community have about our group and the way it's run, which gradually we are correcting.

The thing, however, that shocked me the most positively since I joined was the scale and the sophistication of our technology. So I would actually go so far as to say, I believe Ping An Group is genuinely one of the most technologically advanced financial institutions in the world. So today, it's with great pressure that we have with us Jessica Tan and key members of her team unveiling what they have built on the technology front over the last 6 years, which goes far beyond Lufax, which of course, we are very proud of.

For those that don't know, Jessica Tan is one of the most senior executives at Ping An Group and the key architect of the technology buildout which we are unveiling today. And I stress the word unveiling, because I do not believe many investors and analysts here today or in our webcast really know what we have done. And I can say this with confidence for the simple reason that we have actually chosen not to externally communicate on it. So what we're going to talk about today is not some new strategy, it's actually what the group has been executing on for the last 5 or 6 years, but we haven't told you.

So in terms of today, Jessica is going to kick off the event with a 30-minute presentation. We'll take a short break, because there's is a lot to digest. And then we'll have presentations from Ericson Chan, who is the CEO of Ping An Tech, and Ricky Ou, who is the Chief Product Officer of Ping An Tech. Expect the presentations will last for about 1 hour 20 minutes in total. We'll take another short break, and then we'll go straight into Q&A.

So with my job done and without further ado, I'll hand you over to our tech guru, Jessica Tan, which is obviously the reason you're here today. So Jessica, thank you.

SIN YIN TAN, CHIEF OPERATION OFFICER, CHIEF INFORMATION OFFICER AND EVP, PING AN INSURANCE (GROUP) COMPANY OF CHINA, LTD.: Hi, good afternoon, everyone. My name is Jessica, and welcome to our discussion today. As James mentioned, very proud to share with you what we've done over the past 5 years. This is something that we believe technology is a core backbone of Ping An Group. It's something that we power not just our core businesses, but has been the source of innovation for many of our new businesses, of which Lufax and Good Doctors are one of many.

So I'll start off with this: everyone -- everything we do is focused on our mission. We want to be the -- we are the largest diversified owner. We want to be the world-leading personal financial services provider. You've seen our 2016 financial performance, very solid revenue profit. And I think we're proud to say that for every customer for our owners we've earned $312 profit. We've also had huge growth as you've seen from our 2016 report. In terms of assets, in terms of scale of our financial services customers, we've also grown very rapidly unlike some of the financial services institution where the Internet users are a fraction -- maybe 1/3 of their total customer base. We've gone the inverse. You see that our Internet user base is almost 3x our financial services customers, and many of which are on our app. And this is a transformation, as James mentioned, that we've been consistently building over 5 years.

Of course -- and you know our ranking. I'll not dwell much on it. But how do we do this? How do we think about doing this? And this is something that I want to share with you today. We really think about it in 2 focus. I think you've always seen that of our core businesses -- in our core traditional businesses, we have our banking, insurance, asset management. And then over the past 5 years, we really created a new set of pillars, what I'll call our new businesses, over 4 ecosystems. And the way we think about our 4 ecosystems is the following: we actually went -- and we believe that financial services will really change in the way that it's been provided to people over the next 10 -- 5, 10 years. And we believe that financial services should not be bought as a product. We believe financial services should actually be integrated with everyday aspects of your life.

So we actually look in a very systematic fashion at each of the industries that we think are most relevant, not just from a GDP standpoint, but also from a individual standpoint. So as you can see here, we think that 4 sectors are most relevant for us and for our customers, all right, financial services itself, real estate, auto and health. We think that it's important to the individuals themselves and to the economy. And therefore, 5, 6 years ago, we then created everything around these 4 ecosystems. And here this is what I want to share with you, really the -- everyone knows about our left-hand side of story in the house, which is really our core businesses. You know our stellar track record in each of our businesses. But I want to share more about -- on the right-hand side of our businesses today and the underlying technology backbone that powers the entire group.

On the right-hand side, this is how we think about this, right. I mentioned, it's really about ecosystem. In each of these 4 ecosystem, our thinking is really how do we to take the technology, and how do we embed financial services into each of these ecosystems so that we can make the lives of the consumers easier so they can work together with the rest of the providers in this ecosystem. So I'll use financial services ecosystem as a start today, just so everyone understands how we think about it.

So traditional financial services institution are traditionally very asset heavy. And so we think about really financial services in a very simplified manner as one in which intermediate between assets and funds, right? And we think about the different business models like traditional businesses. Essentially, they do the business themselves, so they will actually have capital themselves to intermediate between the 2 providers.

Lufax for us was the very first company that we incubated to do -- in marketplace. And idea, as everyone know and many of you are familiar with our Lufax is the marketplace whereby we try to get buyers and sellers have access on our platform, so that is a marketplace that can sell much more efficiently. And we, as a platform provider, use our technology, use our risk, so we have our KYC and our KYP to better assess the needs of the customer and the needs of the product providers and do the matching, right? That's really what the open marketplace is. But not many know that beyond Lufax, over the years we've incubated yet another company, we call OneConnect. And we think this is an even newer evolution of the model, is an even asset lite, it's a pure technology FinTech open platform model, whereby we -- already serves about 200 banks and 2,000 nonbank financial institutions and purely using our technology. And that for us is a breakthrough. It's a breakthrough whereby we created a business purely based on the strengths of our technology. And we believe just as how the technologies have helped our core business grown very successfully, we think that we can also offer it to the rest of the 2,000-over institutions in the financial services ecosystem and help them make their business better. So Lufax, everyone is very familiar with. Everyone might ask me very complicated, legal and organizational structure of Lufax. But in its essence, it's really about an online matching platform, right? So you hear very much what our Lufax cliques will mention, the know your customer and know your products. And in the essence that's what it does, right, which we spend a lot of time investing over the past 6 years, technology about better assessing customer needs be it retail institutional investors and the product. What kind of products, what are risk rating then to do matching? This is the heart of what Lufax does.

Something a little bit less known about Lufax. Actually, last month, along with our Chairman, I was in Nanning, right, a small -- quite a small city within China. But one of the innovations that we've taken now and applied the same concept is actually helping the government manage the asset liability. So if you look in the local Chinese press, you'll see that the entire Nanning government's finances and over 200 companies which are state-owned within Nanning, their asset liability was actually run on our cloud platform. This is a -- something that Lufax can constantly reinventing itself. We want to use the same things that we've been doing on the online matching market dimension. And we will like to try using that to help the government manage the finances. So it was really cool, the facility of Nanning. We actually had the first online whereby the government actually issued one of the -- that online was an auction, it was a blind auction. We were able to help then reduce the financing cost by 14 bps in that transaction. And we're really very proud of this new invention, and we hope that we can continue to do so for other governments.

I want to then move on to OneConnect. This is perhaps -- we've publicized much less. This is -- the idea was really simple. We want to take what we have been using over the past 30 years, technology that we've -- helped our own core business, and we want to do it to the entire financial services ecosystem. As you can see, the financial services ecosystem is -- (foreign language), just RMB 200 trillion in assets, and we are only RMB 6 trillion to RMB 7 trillion assets, so we want to do the whole market, so we started the banks. Banks has -- owns -- has about 87% of the assets and profits in the whole of the China financial services market, and then we created something called a bank connect 3 years ago. And we started off with just 1 bank, a little bank called Taizhou Bank and they really tried to help it. And then today, we have about 200 over banks and 2,000 nonbanks using the platform. And the idea is really simple. We created this whole FinTech layer where we connect to each of these bank's core systems platform. And then on top of it, they can run -- we'll run the white label apps for them. We'll run their SME loans. They will go through our platform. We help them assess the risk. And they can do interbank trading.

So for example, last year alone, we just -- we had RMB 1 trillion in interbank trading on this platform. Right now, another example, we have Bank of Shanghai, which is very large bank. I think it's one of the top 3 banks in Shanghai of RMB 1 trillion in assets. Their entire direct banking mobile runs on our platform. They will actually pay us, whereby we will run and acquire customers, and we'll do promotions, everything for them. So this is something that we're very excited, because we find that if technology can help our own businesses, we can also help the remaining of the financial services sector.

So this is a little bit what we offer. We usually don't share with the public. And I think James say that, we feel really bad at IR, so he specially organized this for us. We've been mostly talking about this to our banking and nonbank institutions. But essentially, what we help them to do is that we help them to do their retail banking. As you know, a lot of the -- there's about 600 small, medium banks in China, which constitute about 40% of the RMB 200-over trillion in assets. And a lot of them are in little cities or provinces. They may not have access to a lot of the technology or the talents that they have. So -- and in retail, given the entire banking pressure they are on, we help them basically do the entire digital banking, right? So they can even tailor. They don't have to change any of their core banking platform, we can tailor various structured products for them. We'll help them develop their own online loan products and all of these just for a fee, right? They're going to have to invest heavily into their own systems. They can be online within 1 to 2 months.

We'll also do their loans. As you know, SME lending is a huge sector and a huge source of the growth in China. There's about CNY 20 trillion in SME loans by these small, medium banks in China every year. And you need -- it's a very face -- very people-intensive, very face-to-face kind of business, and we provide a platform, it is actually there's some Blockchain involved in it, whereby, we help them get real time information about their individual SMEs and can help them better access, and then we charge them a fee for it. And then as I said, the asset -- inter FI asset trading, the small, medium banks every year has bout RMB 650 trillion in trading. But 2/3 of them is actually very inefficient, because a lot of them don't have very nationwide networks. They are not able to -- they go through brokers, right? So they're much higher fee. Going through our platform can help them reduce their financing cost by 5, 10 bps, and they can do it directly with them. It's a fully Blockchain thing. We've actually taken Smart Contract concept, and we've built this where they can issue their own products on Blockchain and then they trade amongst themselves. So far, it has been about RMB 1.3 trillion on our Blockchain asset platform, and we are really excited about that.

And then one of the things we've taken even one step further, last month -- because we have this alliance about 224 banks with us. Last month, we tried something even more interesting. We said, look, we're too slow and there's too many of you. I mean, we're not enough to tailor everything for you, so we did an open API platform. So last month, we've launched this. We have over 300 APIs. There are standard APIs that they can connect to, and we make that open to them. We already have about 34 banks with their own technology team and their vendors who will develop apps and systems on our platform. And we think that will even accelerate the progress, because it's simply such a huge market. So we're very excited about this kind of new model. This epitomize what our entire group thinks about moving -- our Chairman will like us to move from one where we use -- I don't know how to translate, using capital to make money to something where equally we use technology to make company. I think, we see ourselves not just as a financial services institution, but very much a technology company at heart, and we hope that this is the beginning of how we are thinking about this.

This is another example. This is a part of our OneConnect platform, one of the modules which is very popular with this. We have many of the -- and we are very glad that many of our global banks, including the likes of HSBC, Standard Chartered, even some of the large banks within China are using our credit bureau. The 85% of the 200 banks and 2,000 FIs that I mentioned use our credit bureau. Just last month alone, we have 88 million enquiries -- loan applications that passes through our credit bureau. And we're very glad because this is something people are using it to base it on their actual loan decision, right? Last year, we have accumulated about 100 million unique borrowers, loan applications coming through us, and we're glad that we're actually helping institutions and helping consumers in that way.

I want to talk a little bit then to our health ecosystem. Something that we're very excited and very important for our consumers. And the way we think about ecosystem, I think in our previous Investor Day, we shared before. We really think about in the 3Ps way, right? Patient or consumer, because they're not sick yet; providers; and, of course, who is paying for it. And the way we think about this is that, we started off as an insurance company where our strength is really how do you manage health-related cost. But in China, as most of you know, the bulk of the health care cost is actually being borne by the social health insurance. So 6 years ago, actually, we started then offering our services to various individual governments on how to manage their social health reimbursements. Today, I think we have over 280 cities or the likes and increasing by the way, whereby you help them manage their social care -- social health care reimbursements.

So Xiamen, for example, that's one of the first cities that we did this for. In Xiamen, a population of 6 million people and 10,000 doctors, every time the doctor in the hospital -- when they prescribe something, it will run through by our engine, whereby we determine what's the right level of reimbursement that we should do, what type -- what's the right level of medication that we should have for this particular patient in this particular illness, and that's real time. I think just alone on average for the cities, we're able to help this -- the government reduce about 14% of their costs. I think this is huge impact for them, not just economically, but socially. As you know, we have a aging population in China. The affordability and sustainability of social health insurance is very important, and we think this is -- this will be very helpful for them.

And then besides on the social health insurance, on the patient side, as many of you in China would know, one of the problems of the health care in China is about having easy access to primary care services, right? Even for flu, often our colleagues will have to take half a day just to go to the hospital for a -- for flu for their kids. So what we started doing is then we created 2 things: we think about having online and off-line. So online was really our Good Doctor, which many of you know about. We are really happy how it's grown. It's only been 3 years, but we have over 150 million users. Every day, we have about 444,000 enquiries on our app. I think that provides -- it shows the need in China for affordable, online, easy primary care questions, right? So usually, they ask simple questions before, then they go to the right doctors.

Then in the off-line, something perhaps that's less known to the public, we have this Wan Jia (foreign language), whereby we try to also upgrade the capabilities of the clinics. Because, I think there are about 1 million-or-so clinics all over in China, we try to have a platform, just like what we've done for OneConnect, but we've then created something based on the standards, DNV and others to -- whereby we have a technology platform and then it has the right standards about how you should manage your patient, your health records, what's the right level so that you can qualify for the social health insurance reimbursements to better manage the health care. And this is something that we started I think about 2 years ago, and we have about -- 1.5 years ago, and we have about 50,000 clinics right now on our platform. And everything on this is actually on the Ping An Health Cloud. We hope eventually that we'll be able to make an impact in the health care economy whereby individuals can have better access in the integrated health records to them. So everything that we have, we connect it to the health cloud. You as a consumer, if you're in a particular hospital, you can actually ask to request and consolidate your health records across these various providers.

So this is an example of the social health insurance that we have, and you see this is Xiamen, this is the first one that I mentioned, where even the CIRC President at that time actually went to visit. It's not only helped save costs, but it's also huge improvement in satisfaction, a great service and then we caught a lot of violation.

We are expanding that actually to not just include social health insurance. In some cities, we're doing a pilot whereby we try to integrate different parts of the city services onto an app for the government. So not just social health care insurance, but we try to do some like their health records, their long-term insurance, public services, various things, and we help the government integrate that into an easy app that the consumers can look into.

This is our Good Doctor. Many of you know. We've grown very rapidly, now about 1,000 full-time doctors. We work with about 600 -- 60,000 part-time doctors. And every day, we have about 40 -- (foreign language), so that's 430,000 queries. Sorry, I have to keep switching between Chinese, English and so my brain is all fried up. But we think this is really helpful. So not -- at first we started doing a free online enquiries. Last year, we actually started to give cards. We have our health card. You can pay about USD 100, right? And you get about 10, 12 times of free enquiries. Then after that, we'll actually have referrals, whereby work with our preferred network and you can get access. You get 1-hour medicine delivery if you live in some of the cities that we do. So we're building a membership around here.

This is the clinic, one that I mentioned. That's about 50,000 of them. There's a extra 0 here, I apologize. And this is something that hopefully over the long term is going to be difficult, but we hope to build a good brand of affiliation of clinics that has good standards.

Then there is 2 I'll just cover very briefly, before we take a short break. There is a auto ecosystem and house, which we also don't spend much time talking about. These are ecosystems that we started to gradually think about. In auto, as some of you may know, we've actually invested in Autohome. Autohome is the largest car portal in China. It has about 76% market share in the market in China. That means every year, there's about 22 million people buying new cars, second-hand cars, 76% of them does it through Autohome. On average, you see that a person who comes here, they'll spend -- someone who wants to buy a car, they spend on average 80 days on our app, our website, looking for the right car that they want and then before they actually go to a preferred dealer through us to buy the car. So we think that it's a wonderful thing, and one of the reason we invest in this because we think there's a lot of synergies for P&C insurance and of course, with our bank. As you know, we are the second-largest car insurer in China. You should -- also know that actually our Ping An Bank is the largest car financing company, both to the dealers as well as the consumers.

And so we wanted to do something for the car owners. So one of the things that we are gradually building, you see in the Autohome car release is that, not only for the customers we serve them, if you're trying to buy a car through Autohome, but also if you already have a car then through our P&C we have app called Good Car Driver. And then -- we're also then working with our ecosystem partners off-line to use it in platform, so that we can better link the customers to the providers.

So for example, therefore, that Autohome has announced that they are doing. Last month, Autohome launched this car dealers. There are 29,000 car dealers in China, that's -- so the bulk of the new cars, we work with them, whereby through this they will get better access to the people who want to buy cars. We'll also offer the right financing and insurance through the platform, both for the dealers as well as to the consumers. We also have second-hand cars. Second-hand cars, as you know, in China is still a very underpenetrated market, but it's going to reverse as I just said in the U.S. Actually, there are 4 second-hand cars sold to every new car, we think that's a trend, but it's a very fragmented market, but now we are also trying to build that so that we can have better access to it.

And then we also have this car components. This is a -- (foreign language) so that's a RMB 400 billion business every year, whereby in parts but a lot of it increasingly is not just through the car manufacturers but is actually through dealers, repair shops. There's about 100,000 repair shops. And this is something that P&C, because we work with all these repair shops, we know exactly the parts, the labor hours of every make across this 100,000 repair shops. Actually, we're now building an open platform whereby people can bid for it. So over time -- this is still in the working stages, but this is something that we think. We have something very interesting in the auto ecosystem, which is a very important part of the economy that over time we hope to solidify.

And then finally, the housing, real estate. I think this is also a very long-time play, but clearly, that's very important for the economy and the consumer. And here, our approach has really been -- we have 2 companies which is also we don't publicize too much. We have a Ping An Haofang, which really is an online housing portal. And then we have a offline mortgage center, which is called (foreign language). And the idea here is that it is a very fragmented market in China, but we want to work what we work best, which is on financial services.

A mortgage in China takes more than a month. I mean, I've never bought a house, but at least my colleagues have done, so you have to make multiple trips to the banks to (foreign language) to get it, right? And what we've done really we take how to really streamline a process, the risk assessment so that we can get it fast as now as 4 days. And so we work with the top 100 developers, the top 100 real estate agency in China, and we try to make financing easy for their customers. And that's how we are thinking about it. Again, this is one of the early stages one, and we welcome any comments as well, but we think this will become a very important part going forward.

So that's really what I wanted to share today at the beginning is really about the right part of our pillar. What I want to impress upon is that we are not just a financial services company, as James mentioned, we are actually very much a technology company. It is actually something that we've been doing consistently over the past 5 to 6 years. The way that we think about technology company is not just for our own consumption, we actually have a very much platform-driven kind of thing, whereby we'll incubate them, we'll put them into ecosystems and we want to share that with the rest of the ecosystem players.

I wanted to -- we want to take a short break, 10 minutes. And then after which, I wanted to invite my colleagues, Ericson and Ricky, who will share with you the technology backbone, the powers behind both the left and the right pillars that I think will be quite interesting. Actually, there a lot of things in our lab that we usually don't share, but James has said that we got be out there to share. So we're happy when -- it is something new for us. So hopefully you enjoy the rest of the discussion.

Okay, I will spend some time here to explain some of the things that Jessica mentioned earlier. One of the key things Jessica mentioned at the beginning is that we have 137 million customer, financial customer, and then we have 376 million online users. That is very, very unusual.

For most banks or insurance company, you -- how do you acquire customer? You acquire customer by selling a financial product. It could be auto insurance, it could be mortgage, could be credit card. You start with that, and once you get a product sold and you try to service them, when you get a chance to service them, you try to do cross-sell. And then, once you bring in the customer, so you also try to migrate them, so called migration, make them online, right? And most of the banks today, it will be hovering around 30% to 40% of the online user base. Ours is completely different. We have -- we're using a different business model. Ours is 270%. How so? We first provide free service to address our customer pain point. These pain point is part of their daily lives. It could be auto, it could be housing, it could be any aspect of their daily life. So we try to use technology. Of course, without recent development of technology, that's not possible because of the cost. Because now we are leveraging technology, we can provide services to everyone free of charge, no different than a lot of the startup today or Facebook, the one that you're very used to today. And this is an example. As you see, the number is 270% of our financial customers are our online users today. This is -- what this app does? This is a one-stop shop for every single thing a car driver or car owner ever needs. It is as simple as, okay, where's your gas station? To how do I do the maintenance of my car? If I need to do maintenance, where can I get a repair shop, a maintenance shop? If you want to read a little bit more about the auto news, it will engage its -- like a Top Gear-ish newsfeed, you can get it. And even one of the most popular functions, that will be managing your traffic ticket, as in China, it is ordeal to manage your traffic ticket. Because sometimes if you register your address wrongly, even if you get a speeding ticket, you might not know. If you don't pay, you get yourself in trouble. So this is an ordeal to manage this in China and this is a pain point, we figure that out. So what we do is -- all you need to do, you don't need to pay anything. And you register your car, and then as soon as -- if you do get a ticket, we will remind you. We will alert you when you need to pay. As soon as you need to pay and you recognize it, if you link to your account, then we will settle the bill for you. So this is a one-stop shop of everything you ever need as a car driver.

Second screenshot from the right. What is that? I don't know if you can read it from the back, this is -- the map actually is, I'm not too proud of it, is about 2 months ago. I was in a hurry. I need to take my son to play badminton. I was late. So I got out from my home, and you'll see some of the red dot is when I turned the corner a bit too fast. When I -- the orange dot is actually is a little rocket picture, that obviously I was driving a little bit too fast. I was in a hurry. So what it does? It able to capture your driving behavior. Why do we do that? Once you capture driving behaviors, so we can alert you. "Hey, if you're driving like this, you're wasting gas." Wasting gas is wasting money. So we are trying to engage you by helping -- it is no different than many of us, is wearing this kind of wearable device so that you know a bit more about yourself. So you can manage everything a little bit better. But, of course, by doing so, we know you a lot better, at the same time, as a company. So once we bring in a new customer, how do we -- because we -- Ping An Group is a huge organization, we have all different financial asset class offering. So -- and for example, we have securities, we have trust, we have bank offering credit cards, mortgages. So if -- once you get one of the products, how can we engage you to a different organization? And we have a very, very unique way, that is called Renyimen. So it's like a -- how do you -- it's almost like a teleportation mechanism. Teleportation between one company or one app to another. If you look at the screenshot at the back -- at the bottom, there is some tiles. Regardless which application you're starting with within the Ping An organization, all of them will have this tile Renyimen teleportation mechanism to tailor-made suggest you what you might need else -- what else you might need. So if your car -- have a car insurance with us, at a certain point in time, if you think certain product, like your credit card, it will fit your lifestyle, we will suggest that. It will -- in one of the tiles, and also suggest other services that might address some of your daily pain point and add value to you. So by doing so, we can get cross -- I don't want to use the word, but there is cross-selling. We can use to do a lot more cross-selling between different products. So there's over 100 million customers of ours, when they get onto a app and they were able to use this mechanism, teleport to another area, another company, another app of ours. So we can engage them and then -- with more products and services.

And in addition, and also you can imagine because of the account structure, it's not -- sometime it's not that simple, by referring you from one entity to another. Therefore, we have another mechanism. It's called master account. So once you tied your primary app with this master account, then you can engage all other products from other app within the entire Group. Make it very seamless, painless. So financial products is painless. That is a new thing. So this is what we have been working on in the last couple of years.

So in the -- so I'll just talk about how we engage customer differently to bring them in and how we transfer from one entity, one asset class, one product to another. But regardless, which product, which services and the back end, we try to digitize, automate everything possible, and we believe in technology, and this is very fortunate of me to be part of this visionary organization, so we can invest and digitize everything. Risk control. Risk is very important for all financial organization. So regardless as therefore, 2C customer or even 2B customer. I don't have any material, but I can also talk about for 2B customer. Speed. Speed is very critical, speed to market, speed to provide services to our customer. And even if you have a new product, a new system -- for those who know, in the industry, you need to get production environment ready. Normally, it will take days, probably weeks before you can get a whole new environment ready. With our home-grown cloud technology, it will take us only 150 seconds. So what are they? First one, perception. Perception, is basically it means, when I see something, can I make some sense out of it? In this particular case, when I look at you, do I know if you are you? Very simple. I want to make sure if you're you. This is beyond what a FinTech normally has scoped. But this is beyond that and this is still, we believe, is core to our business. Because is this important is security and also is great convenience for our customer.

So very happy that. In June, we have hit world #1 on accuracy, our facial recognition engine, according to the LFW benchmark. In June, we topped the world. That is fantastic, and we just had a celebration party last night. Thank you for the budget, boss. And then -- and 300 million usage. This is only since the beginning of last year. Since beginning of last year, we have 300 million times being used this model. But every time when you use it, the engine will get more -- the model will get more and more accurate. At a peak time, this is a geek number, we was very proud, 30,000 faces we process in a minute.

And -- so what does it mean? It's very exciting for a techie like myself, but there will be more cases Ricky will explain later on. But I'll highlight just one case, how we have been using it. For example, one of our loan product -- personal loan product (foreign language), it is called iLoan, you have an app on your phone, you download it, you need to -- if you need to apply for loan, you take a few photos of your own ID and some of the supporting document and then you click it, you will engage one of our agents through a video conference as face time as video conference, and we'll start to ask a few questions. So I think that's one way in which we've not able to create value, so that our core business can constantly stay at the top of their game. The second way which we are trying to create value, I think this one takes a little bit while is the right (inaudible) side of the house I mentioned. We're trying to take that and say, look just serving our own businesses is not sufficient. We hope that each of these company, the Lufax, the Good Doctor, the OneConnect, the Social Health Insurance over time, becomes actually standalone, viable technology companies themselves serving the external market. I'm pleased to say, actually, over the past 6 years, about 3 to 4 of our Internet companies have actually broke even and start making money. Now a lot are still in the investment phase, which used to do so just like Amazon -- I mean, you cut your tech Amazon, the famous story AWS, they lost for 11 years. So we believe in the tech platform story, you need to invest in the beginning, but once you get in, you get the scale. And so hopefully, over the next few years, you start to see value also from the right-hand side of the house.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: The second question is that the how to resolve the conflict of interest with your customer? So it means that you are as a Ping An Group is a financial institution and the way you provide a tech service, it's great. It's of financial cloud from their technology, but your customer is also a financial institution. In some degrees, they are competing with Ping An as a group. So can you show some example how you resolve the issue and become profitable, I mean, business?

SIN YIN TAN: So I think we do that in 3 levels. One is that, legally, we create separate legal infrastructure. So they're really, I mean, Ping An is a very competitive group. We compete internally too. So we're all P&L driven. They're completely separate businesses. So for the OneConnect I mentioned, it's a completely separate business. And they treat Ping An bank like 1 of the 200 banks that they serve. At a security technical level, each one of these, because remember even without serving the external banks and the FIs actually, internally, we have to manage also 28 companies differently. Each one of them actually have a different regulator. We can't really share and stuff like that. So over the years, we've built our infrastructure the way we segregate our data, even now cloud. One of the unique things about cloud is that we are able to -- our VPCs, virtual private networks, is such that we really segregate, but in some cases, we physically segregate. But we're able to dynamically do that as well. And we've been doing it over the past 20 years for our company. So at the beginning of cost, there is a third thing, which is trust factor. I mean, I can tell you I do that and stuff. People may not still trust me. So it took a while, right, to be honest. Our OneConnect started 3 years ago. The first one took a while. But after that, people believe us more and more. I mean, the Bank of Shanghai example you mentioned now has been running live for 9 months, right, and all their customers say, we will not compromise. I think, may ultimately because we are regulated entity, we never compromise. Because the one time we do something like that where we use your customer information that we shouldn't, I mean, we're dead. We're dead not just in terms of our new business, but our core businesses as well. So this is something we take very seriously.

ERICSON CHAN: If I may just add one more line. So some of the customer really just told us if it's good enough for Ping An, got to be good enough for me. So there's -- because they believe that if we can serve Ping An well enough scale and speed and security, they are more and glad to join.

JAMES GARNER: Right, next question. The gentleman over there.

KAILESH MISTRY, HEAD OF FINANCIALS EQUITY RESEARCH, ASIA-PACIFIC AND ANALYST, HSBC, RESEARCH DIVISION: It's Kailesh Mistry from HSBC. I got a couple of questions. The first one is just philosophically, why did you develop the technologies in-house? You could have gone externally. And then the second question is, given the business is very P&L focused, I got a good feel of effectively the service provision to then feed into product provision. Could you give us an idea of how management is incentivized to encourage the behavior to benefit the rest of the Group?

SIN YIN TAN: Sir, is the second question is how do you incentivize management?

KAILESH MISTRY: How is your -- the technology sort of stream of management incentivized to effectively provide the services and then cross-sell into the rest of the Group, because you know the service initially is free.

ERICSON CHAN: Okay. Quite -- first, to begin first of all, we have the scale. And many, the customer base look fortunate for us, the customer base that we have is probably bigger than a lot of the tech company customer base to begin with. And -- but that is not the core reason. And some of the things that -- of course, we spend like, for example, talk about facial recognition. And those in the market today or when the time that when we first started, it just wasn't good enough for us. And then we have tested the accuracy, the interoperability. And then I just also mentioned it does not have a Chinese face model some of the -- for international supplier. So therefore and we start to develop. And once we gain scale ourselves and gain a capability, we figure out actually we can do a better control of the quality and a direction of the technology capability of that products that we have been developing. So -- and then it's like a positive cycle and it was -- see the advantage then we just continue to do more. Not necessary that we are doing everything in-house. But a lot of it is a bit more than normal financial institute for sure. Sometimes, we also collaborate. Collaborate with other higher universities. Sometimes, for example, some of the latest leading-edge technology we'll be working with MIT universities like that so to help each other. I just met with them this morning in fact, it was like MIT professor in Hong Kong. So we'll figure out what else we can codevelop. So it's not pure together, but we case-by-case basis look into it.

SIN YIN TAN: And I think that just on the first one I want to just emphasize a lot about making, because all of us have technology background. Often, it's just not about the technology, it's about how you make it work and that's where the secret sauce is, right? The face one is very practical, not just they cannot recognize Asian face, there are some local vendors too. But we need -- it's not just accuracy rate. A lot of people don't advertise false positive rate. That's very important for financial services. I cannot wrongly identify that that's the right person. And we need to be (inaudible) 0.0001%, right? And most people (inaudible) don't have that need. So we have to do it ourselves. On your second question about how do we incentivize, it's a multifaceted way of incentivizing, because we're asking our tech people to do a couple of things. So there's 3 things we try to measure them on. I think one is stability and security. That is at the heart of everything. This is a, I mean, you die. We often tell them, it doesn't matter how many facial recognition you do, number one, but it would have a big security or stability risk, you're dead. And so this is why, I think, Ricky mentioned this disaster recovery. Every year, we do this. We imagine the entire year data center got burned or something. And we have to recover everything on the other side. When I first came 5 years ago, I think we were at 20-something hours recover. We are now at 4.3 hours last year. We haven't done one this year. We will usually do in Q3. Every year, we do that, right, so that's -- I think that's number one. Number two is then about service. So we actually have a very complicated back to back anonymous satisfaction level, not just the usual service SLAs that most banks, global banks do, but like a satisfaction and then for all the BUs et cetera. So we make sure that what we're really doing is what they want. And then thirdly, to incentivize on innovation we have stock options incentives just like any other Internet companies. So actually, our tech employees are one of the very rare exception. They get actually options in some of the businesses we're incubing, because a lot of businesses are incubated from them. We want them to say, look, it doesn't matter where you incubated, right? It's like you can give birth but you don't need to grow, you didn't need the ones to raise them, right? Somebody else can do it and you will still get the benefits. So that's how we incentivize.

JAMES GARNER: Next question. MW?

MYUNG WOOK KIM, VP, JP MORGAN CHASE & CO, RESEARCH DIVISION: This is MW Kim from JPMorgan. I have 2 questions. One is about the road map for your AI development. So my understanding is there is a two-way of the AI development, as a financial institution perhaps analyzing precise data in a very speed way only about the customer finance information or the numeric data would be a one way. The other way is interrelating the images and thumb should be another one, IBM Watson should be a good example on that. So I want to know as a financier-backed FinTech company, so what would be the real road map for the AI for Ping An? The next question is about whether you are really focusing on the forecasting the claim for the customer in the process of underwriting? So many insurance company nowadays is filtering the customer, forecasting their customers, their input data and then that they use it in the underwriting and the screening and make their loss ratio better. Do you have this kind of underwrite process currently or are you planning to do that, if not?

RICKY OU: The road map. Yes, so I'll take the -- take a shot at the first question first, the road map. Yes, in terms of AI road map, we're going in 2 direction. One is going at the depth. And the other one is the breadth. Okay. First of all, the depth. So as you saw earlier, we do facial recognition, right? So that's just telling who you are. The next step we are going to do is facial analysis. So the things I mentioned earlier, micro-expression. So we will be able to currently recognize 19 different micro-expression on your faces and be able to infer about a nice state of emotion state. The levelness of being happy, your anger, frustrated and so on and so forth, right? So with that, we have actively incorporate that into our micro loan process. So in a way to trying to see whether you are nervous when you're being asked questions, so we drill down further. So technically, like, do you lie, right, that scenario, right? And the other dimension, we had a goal with AI is the breadth, right? So earlier, we mentioned we have facial recognition. We're going to have sound. Down the road, we're going to do retina and also the breadth, the vein recognition. Why? Why do we do that? Because for every single biometric, there's always a weaknesses. So for example, fingerprint, it used to be like they are very bulletproof, but now in Taobao for maybe $10, you can buy a fingerprint mold that you can fool about 60% of the fingerprint. And same thing with facial. I mean, you can take someone's selfie recording and you can fool a lot of the facial recognition system, right? Now what we do in the future, we're going to combine those, such as facial and voice together. And when you combine the 2 together, your level of safety would increase dramatically, right, because it will be very difficult for you to fake both at the same time, right?

SIN YIN TAN: So I'm not sure if we fully answered your question, I'll try the second one, right? And (inaudible). So I think in auto, we're doing 3 areas where we are focusing on. One is in terms of rating. And we do for new customers and renewal. And then one is in terms of claims. And then one is in terms of servicing, right? And I'll just give examples of how we think -- what we do. So on the rating, we don't just look at your past claims, because frankly, everyone has access to that. In China, there are -- this is publicized, right, who has claim, not claim, et cetera, that itself then you just have the same rating card, which is why you see in China, most of the insurers compete the same price, right? But what we do is actually look deeper into what, for example, what a bad driver Ericson is in his little car, a Good Car Driver App. But we also correlate with actually other data because of richness of data. So one interesting thing you see depending on your occupation, I'm not going to tell you which occupation it is, you actually have 5x higher a chance of accident than others just by simple -- because we have transferred the record and we have things. We're actually looking to stuff in terms of health. There is a high correlation between people with high blood pressure with bad drivers. I'm not sure how much causality or correlation there is. But these are interesting things that I think because of the richness of things we're going to do. With claims, we tend to do, as I said, the damage assessment is not just identifying automatically which part is being damaged and how much. Because we have accumulated millions and millions of parts over the years, how much it costs, we are now 85% accurate in terms of predicting how much the price is. That's why in the example that Ericson mentioned, we can give you the money so confidently, because we're quite sure. I mean, 85% is still not good enough, we are aiming for 90% at the end of the year. And these are some of the things we do. Servicing, the same thing. We have these little chatbots. If you try, if you're a customer, you can try our online check. 93% of our online inquiries are being answered by robots that we've trained over the years. And so these are things that we did apply on.

JAMES GARNER: Great. Next question. Gentleman over there.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I'm from Nomura. I'm the insurance analyst. My question is regarding your tech application. Do you face some challenge from regulation? And what's the key challenges?

SIN YIN TAN: Can you give an example of what kind of regulation you think we might face challenge with?

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Sorry, such as recently have some headwinds on the P2P, right, you have some new regulations so -- et cetera?

SIN YIN TAN: So actually, in our previous press review, this question was asked me as well. I think what you see in China over the past 5 years, what core Internet finance (inaudible) is a bit different from, I think, what we're trying to say today, which is FinTech. (inaudible) really is the P2P companies is the best example, are actually, institutions who are trying to do financial services but just on the Internet. So they're actually a loan company. So -- I think which is why you see over the past year plus, a lot of regulations have come up, because these used to be completely unregulated entities. And then, we've realized that, hey, these companies are actually doing financial services; therefore, they should be subjected to some regulations, right? So I think that has been the context, which is a bit different from what we are talking about today. Today, we are talking about technology itself that has existed for decades as long as serving financial institutions. So we are not doing the business of the (inaudible), we are saying how do we use technology to help institutions who have licenses do their financial services better by doing their service better, by doing their sales better, by doing their risk control better. So I think it's not really impacted by any of the regulations that's being discussed today.

JAMES GARNER: Next question. Charles?

CHARLES ZHOU, VP, CRéDIT SUISSE AG, RESEARCH DIVISION: This is Charles from Crédit Suisse. So I have 2 questions. First of all, it's about your -- so you talk about the voiceprint recognition, face recognition. And I also noticed you used the word (inaudible) used by Lufax and P&C. So can I ask you like can you give us a number or something that how much you have already used those AI technology in your business? For example, maybe 10% of your car claims has been used this technology? Or can you quantify this one, because I think (inaudible) one get a feeling whether there is something and also how much you have already used now and also -- so like how much has been really put into the reality, in the implementations? And also besides Lufax and P&C, what other Ping An business or units can also use this maybe in the future? So this is the first question. And the second question, I think you probably already talked about this one, but compared with other big TMT firms, BAT whatever, can you maybe talk about great strengths, Ping An compared with them and also the 3 challenges?

SIN YIN TAN: Yes, sure, sure. I think on the first one, it depends by different technology, because we have different stages. So facial, for example, is very widely used. Already, I think about 10 of our companies use it on securities -- sorry, 17, I'm sorry. So almost all. You can do the calculation there. Our securities company use it for their account opening. Credit card will use it, et cetera, et cetera. Voice recognition is something relatively new. We've been working with MIT for 3 years on this. And it is now in the first phase of actual live testing. It's actually really difficult, because just we're trying to develop a fingerprint for the voice. A normal person can only differentiate about 100 to 150 people's different voices. You have to train the machine to recognize 1 billion people. And we've been able to make the breakthrough actually earlier this year. So we've just -- we're just launching. So we will be applying, I think, this year in 3 areas in our call center. We have about 200 million calls every year. So we'll be using that. If you are a customer, you can try that now, because a lot are self-service. Our self-service rate today is only 50% on the phone IVR. That's already much higher than, I think, most of the -- most financial institutions in China is about 30%. We expect to increase that to 80%, 85%, because a lot people stop in the self-service because they forgot their PIN number. They forgot their card number. So we're going to use the voice print and do that. And we're very confident we can do that, because we've been recording these people's voices for years. So I think that one is still relatively new. We'll start the call center. We're doing the P&C and Lufax. And then, next month, you see we'll actually simultaneously launch to other financial institutions. So one of the things to just show how serious we are on the right-hand side of our house, we are going to offer it to other financial institutions even before the rest of our companies have used it. We want to give it a level playing field. Whoever wants to use it essentially incentivize their own companies to come and use it. So that's your first question. On the second question, what's our relative strengths and weaknesses compared to some of the TMT companies. I'll start with the weaknesses first. (inaudible) yes, one is that they have a much more online users traffic than us, right, after all we did start off that way, right? So we now have 400 million Internet users. They have 800 million, 900 million, right? So we caught up, but not yet. The second thing is just the frequency of the data, right? Many of the social chats, et cetera, they've lot more data than we do. And then, third one, they have much higher valuation. So they can afford to burn much better than us. So I think these are the 3 weakness I can think about. I think in terms of strengths though over the past 5 years, we've also found unique strengths, which is why we're quite confident here. I think the first strength is actually on the traffic. We've realized that in financial services and health, it's not like selling a commodity item. The face-to-face matters, right? Just our Lufax, for example, 50% of people who try to open account actually stop halfway online. They do it by us calling back or via agents kind of being there. And then once they get on, they're much better, right? The face-to-face does matter and China is so big. Most of them are not as savvy and educated as some of the younger generation in Tier 1 cities. And that's been a huge source. Our 1.4 million agents is wonderful, they can sell anything. Jahwa, for example, which is one of the companies we own for cosmetics skin care, we are now their largest distribution channel because our guys can sell it. And I think that's very unique for us. The number two, I think, is in terms of data, we've realized that it's not just about having lots of data. I mentioned earlier it's about having the richness and accuracy of the data. We have 880 million people's data, all of which we know exactly who they are. We don't have to guess. I mean, if you are a search engine, actually, a lot of the AI is spent guessing who you are. We try to guess whether you are a male or a female, who -- or who are you, we don't have to guess. Our customers told us. And I think that's the advantage of the data plus the track record, so we can build models. And then the third thing, I think, is about risk and security, right? We grow up that way in the way that we do our financial services product risk control, in the way in our system stability and even how we deal with regulators, right? In China, the regulation is very unique. It's not a nationwide regulation. It has nationwide regulation plus local regulation. And you need to have presence in local regulators, because if customers complain, they have to go to somebody, right? If you're one on Internet, which is why you see over the past few years is some of the TMT players have launched these Internet finance companies. They can't do a lot of -- none of that has done car, for example, they can't do car insurance, because you need to have local guys who can service. And I think we are able to do that. So I think these 3 strengths really make us quite unique and very interesting.

JAMES GARNER: Next question. Gentleman over last.

KELVIN CHU, ASSOCIATE ANALYST AND DIRECTOR, UBS INVESTMENT BANK, RESEARCH DIVISION: This is Kelvin Chu from UBS. Can you talk about on the life insurance business, in addition to underwriting efficiency, what kind of technology should we expect in the next 2 years for the life business that will help Ping An Life to further differentiate from peers? My second question is simple one. So 20,000 of highly intelligent individuals, are they just on AI or technology overall?

SIN YIN TAN: You want to answer the second question?

ERICSON CHAN: A lot of it is making not only on AI, but is making new technologies. So it could be making changes automating. So these are driving change for the entire group. That is what the 20,000 technologists is for. It's not like not keeping the lights on if this is what you're talking about.

SIN YIN TAN: On that, I'll just add, right, it's the impressive growth. 5 years ago, when I first came, we only had 4,000 developers. Today, we have 20,000. Not only that the number that Ericson showed earlier, I can't remember 60% or something, we delivered in 2 weeks. 5 years ago, it was like 70% in one month. So we've maximized our capacity 10x over the 5 years in terms of what we can churn out. And that's just in 5 years. Imagine what it would be next 5 years. So I think that that is just a scale and speed in which we're doing, right? To your first question about life insurance, I think there's really 3 areas. It's not just what is coming, but we've been actually consistently doing. I think besides underwriting, one is basically our agency productivity, right? You've seen and lots of analysts ask us at every road show, why is that we've been able to have a much higher productivity at a much larger scale, as some of our competitors have close to our productivity, but they have 1/10 of this -- this was our scale. And this is really because 10 years ago, already, our Chairman had said, they want to make each of our agents like James Bond. We got to make them equipped with technology. So that any of the agent who come, they can sell any product. And not because they are so smart or anything, we have our training app. We have a wonderful training app that we did this year. It's online training app, whereby they can simultaneously -- [football] was the craze in China last year. We actually had to support for our training, 1.4 million agents being trained on new stuff. We equip their laptop or the iPad with something as a remote. We had this 4 years ago already, whereby over 3G, you can have a video connection with our investment specialists in our centralized contact center, so that with their customer, they can appear professional. That's how they can sell. So I think that's one area we're consistently working at. And you can expect us to continue doing so in the future. And then the third area is the servicing. I think one thing that you will see is that we're going to not only have the checkbox that I mentioned in improving our IVR and stuff, but we are going to radically change how our counter -- actually, we're shocked that we still have a few thousand life insurance servicing people on the counter, which is actually highly inefficient, because the amount of time the people come to you is announced. So we're going to actually radically change that and make it much more automated and self-service.

JAMES GARNER: So we'll take a final question and then Jessica will wrap up. Lady in the front.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: (foreign language) I want to know which part you invested the most? And what's your focus on the next step incubation?

SIN YIN TAN: (foreign language) Finance and the health care are our 2 focuses. So in terms of these 2 areas, we are -- that's what we have invested in for the past 5 years. And we will continue to do in the next 5 years. And we haven't done many areas in the health care industry, such as the pricing reform. But pricing reform is only one part of it. We hope we can -- so we have the city OneConnect, and we want to develop more. So in these 2 ecosystems, you can see we will go very in-depth, such as the OneConnect I mentioned. We have over 200 banks and over 2,000 financial institutions. But their product is only -- average product is only 1.4. So we can go much deeper than that. So in the next 5 years, we have a lot of things to do. And in the other ecosystem, such as the auto and the real estate, we will take gradual long time to develop that areas. And the Autohome, we acquired actually is only 1 year. You can see Autohome stock, the share price has increased 50% since we joined. And they also brings us the benefits because P&C and the Ping An Bank are off-line branches and outlets. But now you can see we can develop a lot, and we have a huge room to develop the auto ecosystem. And also, real estate is also a long-term plan.

JAMES GARNER: That's it for today's event. Thank you very much for your attendance. I'm not sure if you want to say a few final words.

SIN YIN TAN: Sure. I just want -- firstly, I just want to thank everyone, particularly for the tech analysts who have joined us. I hope you will come to us more often. We will love if you bring us new ideas. It's a whole different world there. And then, I think all we want to take away today is that, I think, don't just look at us on the left side of the house, we're very impressive. But hopefully, on the right side of the house, we'll equally bring you value and then hopefully more will come. Thanks very much.

JAMES GARNER: Thank you.

ERICSON CHAN: Thank you.

RICKY OU: Thank you.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60Y9-WPG1-DY7V-G1SX-00000-00Pinterest is this year's best social media stock2020-09-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:38ZLexisNexisPinterest is this year's best social media stockNEW YORK (CNN Business)

NEW YORK (CNN Business) -- Facebook, Twitter and Snapchat get all the buzz in the social media investing world. But Pinterest has sharply outperformed them all in 2020.

Pinterest stock is up nearly 125% this year, easily outpacing Facebook's more than 25% gain and the 40% and 60% jumps for Twitter and Snap.

And several analysts think the image-sharing site has even more upside, thanks to Apple's new look.

Apple's recent iOS 14 release includes a folder-heavy update that makes it easier to customize iPhone home screens. As a result, there have been several reports about Pinterest downloads hitting records on the App Store in recent weeks, along with people tweeting screengrabs of their new home screens and citing Pinterest posts as an inspiration.

"More users are coming on board following iOS 14," said DJ Kang, CEO of Value Champion, an investing research website. "That's attractive to advertisers."

Kang noted the uptick in Pinterest downloads since Apple released iOS 14, adding that sustained interest in the social media firm could help boost its monetization rates internationally. Currently, the average revenue per Pinterest user in the US is more than three times that of revenue for international users.

Pinterest's new Story Pins feature, which lets creators post a mix of photos, video, audio and text, could help the company attract more users, Kang added -- particularly Gen Z consumers who have flocked to Snapchat, Facebook-owned Instagram and embattled video app TikTok.

Still, Pinterest may also need to prove to Wall Street that it can be consistently profitable for the long haul. The company has lost money in its past two quarters after eking out a profit in the fourth quarter of 2019.

There is hope that Pinterest may be finally turning a corner, though.

Analysts are currently forecasting that Pinterest will post a small profit for 2020 and that earnings will surge in 2021. And 20 of the 28 analysts who follow Pinterest have raised their price target on the stock since the company reported second quarter results in late July.

Pinterest might also be benefiting from the fact that it's still relatively small compared to the likes of Facebook and other tech and social media behemoths like YouTube owner Google.

While most Big Tech firms have come under intense scrutiny from Washington and antitrust authorities around the globe, Pinterest -- with just 96 million monthly active users in the US and 321 million internationally -- could continue to fly under the regulatory radar.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WPX-F4B1-JBRW-X2XG-00000-00Pinterest Proves Challenging Facebook's Social Media Supremacy Is Still Possible2019-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:38ZLexisNexisPinterest Proves Challenging Facebook's Social Media Supremacy Is Still PossibleSissi Cao

In the white-hot space of social media and online advertising, it seems as though nobody other than iron-fisted antitrust regulators could challenge the dominance of   Facebook and   Google. But as some of their smaller rivals have proven, there's still room to win a slice of the pie when the game is played right.

The latest challenger to the Facebook-Google duopoly is Pinterest. Once thought to be a niche site for home decor- and recipe-obsessed housewives, the online scrapbook surprised Wall Street on Thursday when it announced that its monthly user count had surpassed 300 million in the second quarter, a decent 30% jump from a year ago.

SEE ALSO: Here's Why Big Tech Wants in on the Current Astrology Craze

Revenue soared even faster at a 62% annual rate to $261 million for the April-June quarter, which spurred Pinterest's management to raise its full-year revenue guidance to $1.12 billion from last quarter's top-end estimate of $1.08 billion.

Thursday's release was Pinterest's first quarterly report as a public company. Investors were so pumped by the growth numbers that they looked past a gaping a $1.16 billion net loss recorded for the quarter (partly due to its costly IPO in April) and pushed Pinterest stock up 14% in the after hours on Thursday-against the backdrop of a bleak market freshly hit by President Donald Trump's new import tariffs against China.

Pinterest co-founder and CEO Ben Silbermann has called his business an "anti-social media platform" because Pinterest's goal is to provide inspiration, rather than connecting people. Yet, its revenue model looks increasingly similar to that of Facebook and Google, AKA advertising.

For the second quarter, advertising sales drove most of Pinterest's revenue growth. After Thursday's earning calls, Silbermann told CNN that the company's future strategy would focus on more "personalized" content curation and "getting better at showing things you love." In other words, more precise targeting and better ROI for advertisers.

"I feel that online advertising often has a bad rap... because you are seeing ads when you don't really need to see them," Silbermann said. "You don't need ads to talk to your friends. You don't need ads to read the news. But if you are re-modeling your home, you do want to see where you can buy that furniture."

Speaking of Pinterest's high-flying stock price right now, Silbermann said he's not too concerned about one-day or two-day fluctuations in share price. "Over the long term, market tends to reward companies that grow their value over time. That's pretty much what we are focused on," he said.

urn:contentItem:5WR2-3YF1-F00X-J22F-00000-00Pinterest Soars as It Reports Blowout Quarter -- What Wall Street's Saying2019-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:16:38ZLexisNexisPinterest Soars as It Reports Blowout Quarter -- What Wall Street's SayingJacob Sonenshine

The online scrapbooking site's beat and raise convinced several analysts to raise their price targets on its stock.

Pinterest's earnings beat and guidance raise is winning over Wall Street analysts, who are increasing their price targets and estimates on the social media stock.

Pinterest was rising 16.4% to $32.93 a share in early trading on Friday.

Loss per share for the second quarter of 2019 came in at an adjusted 6 cents, of 8 cents and an improvement from the year-ago quarter's loss of 27 cents. Revenue was $261 million, growing 62% year-over-year, and beating analyst's estimates of $236 million.

Management also raised guidance for 2019 and said it now expects revenue of between $1.095 billion and $1.115 billion, compared to a previous range of $1.055 billion and $1.080 billion. Adjusted EBITDA is now expected to come in for full year 2019 at between a loss of $25 million and $50 million, narrower than a prior range of a lost between $45 million and $70 million.

Here's what analysts said about Pinterest's robust quarter:


Credit Suisse, Neutral, Price Target Raised to $33 From $28

"As we have previously noted, Pinterest is just starting to ramp its Int'l sales effort as it exports the products it has already built for the US. Similar to the ad monetization ramp on other properties, Pinterest disclosed that ad volume drove nearly all of the revenue growth - given the more nascent monetization levels, we believe that the company will continue to ramp the ad load to keep pricing at attractive levels in a bid to garner more revenue dollars. We believe there remains potential for upside to both 3Q19 and 4Q19 revenue estimates as the updated FY19 guidance calling for $1.095-1.112b in revenue implies that the nominal dollars of revenue ramp particularly in the US is lower than that of 2H18."


- Stephen Ju


D.A. Davidson & Co., Neutral, Price Target Raised to $28 From $23

"Once again, we were encouraged by the improving international monetization results. For 2Q19, its U.S./International audience (MAU) mix was 28%/72%, while its monetization (revenue) mix was 91%/9%. This compares against 32%68% and 95%/5% respectively, from last year. A more even distribution of revenue may inspire us to upgrade shares in the future."

"We were excited to hear about Pinterest's efforts to expand video content on its platform. Management noted more videos were viewed in 2Q19 than all of last year combined. Note, we believe the rollout of 5G broadband wireless could be a catalyst for its video efforts. Additionally, we were encouraged by Pinterest's efforts to make its platform easier for consumers to shop."

"Management answered our question on the call regarding regulatory risk and big tech, including increasing concerns about privacy. We believe, Pinterest's privacy-related strategy provides it a competitive advantage against Facebook and Google, which is becoming increasingly important in today's global regulatory environment."


- Tom Forte


Pivotal Research Group, Hold, Price Target Raised to $32 From $29

"BOTTOM LINE: We are increasing our PT from $29 to $32 based on 12x 2020 EV/Revs but remain hold rated on the stock based purely on valuation. Given how relatively new the street is to the PINS story and management team, the jury was out as to whether the management team's style would be conservative with revenue guidance for the year - particularly after Q119. Based on 2Q19 results, they feel more likely conservative than we or investors had thought. There were encouraging metrics around shopping feeds, an extremely constructive tone, and continued roll out to new countries - expanding to 19 countries from 13 at in the quarter Q119."

"There is now likely upside for 2H19 based on the Q219 10% beat, and some flow through to the FY19 guidance."


- Michael Levine


Nomura Instinet, Buy, Price Target Raised to $39 From $34

"Canada was cited as an early success story (4x YoY growth in 2Q19) and the company is confident in its expansion playbook. We reiterate our Buy rating and our target price goes to $39."


- Mark Kelley
